Text saved: In 2003, Suzanne Collins watched TV one night. The US was fighting a war in Iraq. She saw shows about young people. They wanted to win money. She also saw news about the war. These two things started to mix. It felt strange to her. So, she got the idea for 'The Hunger Games'.
Feedback received: Grade 7/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Vocabulary Deviation. The text contains a word classified above the A2 level. The word 'fighting' in the sentence 'The US was fighting a war in Iraq' is a B1 level word. A2 vocabulary must be strictly adhered to. All other aspects, including factual integrity, meaning preservation (MeaningBERT 0.854), fidelity (BERTScore 0.9199), and overall CEFR classification (A2), were acceptable. Suggestion: Replace 'fighting' with a simpler A2 phrase such as 'The US had a war' or 'The US was in a war'.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In 2003, Suzanne Collins watched TV one night. The US was in a war in Iraq. She saw shows about young people. They wanted to win money. She also saw news about the war. These two things started to mix. It felt strange to her. So, the idea for 'The Hunger Games' came to her.
Feedback received: Grade 10/10 - PASS

metadata.feedback_text: PASS: The text successfully meets all CEFR A2 readability standards. No deviations were found. Factual Integrity: All facts, numbers, names, and the core message from the original text are accurately preserved. Meaning and Fidelity: The MeaningBERT score of 0.8649 (above the required 0.75) confirms excellent preservation of the core message. The BERTScore of 0.9218 (above the required 0.90) indicates strong lexical fidelity to the original. CEFR Compliance: The CEFR classifier correctly rated the text as A2. Qualitative Audit: Vocabulary: All vocabulary used is appropriate for the A2 level. The word 'hunger' is part of a proper noun ('The Hunger Games') and is therefore exempt from the general vocabulary level assessment for simplification. Structure: The text uses short, simple sentences. Connectors are limited to 'So', which is appropriate for A2. The simplification of complex phrases such as 'flipping between channels' to 'watched TV', 'US invasion of Iraq' to 'US was in a war in Iraq', 'competing to win a million dollars' to 'wanted to win money', and 'merge together in a disturbing way' to 'started to mix. It felt strange to her' demonstrates effective A2-level simplification without losing core meaning.
